The danger I see with the disease model is that it blames one's 
 drinking on this imaginary behavioral disorder. It feeds into the AA 
 myth that will power is useless against this "cunning, baffling 
 disease". It is important to remember that 12-step philosophy 
 considers alcoholism to be a disorder of thinking - not a weakness 
 of will. As such, it deems thinking for oneself to be a 
 manifestation of the disease (stinking thinking / your best thinking 
 got you here... etc). 
 
 Remember the emphasis that is currently given to "denial", the 
 imaginary thought disorder that tells you that you don't have a 
 disease. I am beginning to realize how important this word is to 
 painting a picture of addiction as a form of "insanity" based 
 on "delusion". This, of course, allows them to disregard any real 
 mental illness, and pretend that the symptoms of depression, anxiety 
 etc are caused by the "disease" of alcoholism, instead. 
 
 This all plays into the belief that addiction is a disorder of 
 thought, rather than an issue of free choice. After all, how can one 
 have a choice to quit if they are in denial of having the addiction 
 in the first place? I am beginning to see how this notion serves to 
 undercut a person's confidence in being able to muster up their own 
 resolve to quit on their own. One becomes convinced that all the 
 will power and volition in the world cannot overcome a disorder 
 of "stinking thinking", so why even try? 
 
 Pardon the long post, but I want to show how many facets of steppism 
 actually follow a very well orchestrated plan. I mean, everytime you 
 hear a slogan that discourages independent thought and that 
 pathologizes "self will", you are experiencing an expression of this 
 disease theory, telling you that you have a disorder of thought and 
 not a weakness of will or resolve. 
 
 This approach covers up conditions which can tax our resolve, like 
 dpression, or being unemployed, or being stuck in a dead end job. 
 Instead of considering these challeges to one's coping mechanisms, 
 and instead of seeing how drinking is used as a way of medicating 
 pain, drinking is said to be the result of an "alcoholic mind". The 
 result? ... everytime you try to deal with your true feelings, you 
 are said to be on a "pity pot", because emoting is a manifestation 
 of indulgent "self will" - the cause of all "character defects", as 
 we all know. 
 
 So what? Why this long-winded discourse? I am trying to tie together 
 a lot of loose ends here and show that the disease model, with it's 
 use of the term, "denial", is just a refinement of the original AA 
 philosophy, and it is perfectly consistent with every slogan you've 
 ever heard in the rooms. It is why I don't think you can reform AA 
 to be more sensitive to those with "dual diagnoses". It is why AA is 
 totally incompatable with a non-disease oriented method of recovery. 
 And it is why notions of free will are incongruent with steppism. 
 Isn't it ironic that psychologists who should be dealing with real 
 mental illnesses induldge in this kind of psycho-quackery that is 
 designed to cover up real affective conditions with talk of thought 
 disorders? Well, that's enough for one post.
